extracted_metadata.Description:
Nairobi, Oct 11, 2007 (The Nation/All Africa Global Media via COMTEX) -- Police should act tough on election violence, Nobel Peace laureate Wangari Maathai has said.   

The Tetu MP said election violence was a sign of immature and irresponsible politics.
extracted_metadata.Title: Act On Poll Violence, Maathai Tells Police

extracted_text:
Nairobi, Oct 11, 2007 (The Nation/All Africa Global Media via COMTEX) -- Police should act tough on election violence, Nobel Peace laureate Wangari Maathai has said.   

The Tetu MP said election violence was a sign of immature and irresponsible politics.   
She appealed to the police to work closely with relevant authorities to ensure that those arrested over such crimes were prosecuted accordingly.   

"It is very disappointing to intimidate each other through election violence and using abusive language on fellow competitors," said Prof Maathai.   

She noted with dismay that women were victims of gangs hired by their competitors in a bid to scare them into giving up their political ambitions.   

Prof Maathai appealed to voters to reject candidates who condone violence.   

The MP made the remarks when she launched the Kenya chapter of the Economic, Social and Cultural Council of the African Union (Ecosocc-AU), which seeks to bring together NGOs from all the 53 African countries, to seek representation at AU meetings.   

Elsewhere, election observers have been asked to work closely with credible media, avoid hate speech, highlight women candidates and maintain impartiality.   

Netherlands Ambassador Laetitia Van der Assum urged the local observers to look out for what was going wrong and also right during the campaigns and polling.   

Saying her Government would not back any political party or presidential candidate, Ms Assum said she was pleased that the campaigns were focusing on issues and no longer on personalities and ethnicity.   

Observation forum   

She was addressing the Press at the Kenyatta International Conference, Nairobi, during the launch of the Kenya Domestic Observation Forum, by one of the electoral commissioners, Mr Jack Tumwa.   

The ambassador repeated her country's call for President Kibaki to renew the contracts of Electoral Commission of Kenya Chairman Samuel Kivuitu, and his deputy, Mr Gabriel Mukele, whose terms are ending on the eve of the polls.   

Said Ms Assum: "I have worked as a manager in the past and don't believe that one should change a team just before a major event. We hope that the contracts would be renewed."   

Mr Kivuitu's ends in December while that of Mr Mukele expires today.
